li.p: Semantic or conceptual based theories of IA
Semantic constraints on IA and the Minimalist Program

subsection.heading: 1.1 Definition of IA
subsection.p: Inalienable possession (IA) is a construal associated with certainstructures which contain two nominals, one which denotes a bodypart and another which denotes the possessor of the body part.

These two nominals form a single constituent when a DP denotingthe possessor (POSS DP) is embedded in a DP denoting the body part(BP DP). The respective order of POSS DP and BP N head varies over languagesand over morphosyntactic classes. In Romance, a pronominal POSSDP is prenominal while the full form is postnominal (1). In Englishthe POSS DP is usually prenominal whether it is a pronoun or a fullDP (2):

(1)
a. le bras de Jean
b. son bras

(2)
a. *the arm of John
b. John's arm
c. his arm
In this configuration, the IA construal is a subcase of the possessiveconstrual. An N denoting a concrete object can replace the BP N:

(3)
a. le livre de Jean
b. son livre

(4)
a. *the book of John
b. John's book
c. his book

Structures like (5) and (6) are thus ambiguous: the head N denoteseither an object physically disjoint from its possessor, such asthe cast of a hand by Rodin which the owner bought (alienable possession), or a part of the possessor's body (inalienable possession, IA):
(5) la main de Jean/sa main
(6) John's hand/his hand
In some languages, however, the IA construal is associated witha structure containing disjoint BP and POSS nominals. French hasa number of such structures, the best known of which are listedbelow.
In structure I (7), the direct object denotes a body part andthe subject denotes the possessor:

(7)
Structure I
a. Jean lève la main.
Jean raises the hand
b. Jean donne la main à Marie.
Jean gives the hand to Marie
In Structure II (8), the direct object denotes the body partbut a Dative nominal, clitic or full DP, denotes the possessor.

(8)
Structure II
a. Je lui prends la main.
I him take the hand
‘I take his hand.’
b. Je prends la main à la petite fille.
I take the hand to the little girl
‘I take the little girl's hand.’
In Structure III (9), the direct object denotes the POSS DP whilethe BP DP is embedded in a PP adjunct to VP:

(9)
Structure III
a. Marie a frappé Jean sur la main.
‘Mary hit John on the hand.’
b. Marie a tiré Jean par les cheveux.
‘Mary dragged John by the hair.’

Such structures, which contain disjoint POSS and BP DPs, arereferred to as ‘inalienable possession structures’. This is a misnomer, as there seem in fact to be no structures, inFrench or in any other language examined from this point of view, which are exclusively associated with the IA construal. Either IA isa subcase of the possessive construal of a DP with genitive (ordative) modifier, or it is construed on certain sentential structureswhich happen to contain a DP denoting a human being and anotherDP denoting a body part.

For example, French has a ‘double object’ structurewhich contains an ACC and a DAT DP. The construal of the DativeDP depends on the lexical choice of verb and direct object. TheDat is construed as GOAL in (10a), SOURCE in (10b), BENEFACTIVE(BEN) in (10c), inalienable possessor in (10d), alienable possessorin (10e), and LOCATION in (10f):

(10)
a. J’ai donné un livre à Pierre.
I gave a book to Pierre
b. J’ai pris un livre à Pierre.
I took a book ‘to’ (from) Pierre
c. J’ai cassé sa tirelire à Pierre.
I broke his piggy-bank to Pierre
d. J’ai tordu le poignet à Pierre.
I twisted the wrist to Pierre
e. Je ne connais pas de maîtresse à cet homme.
I do not know (of) any mistress to that man
f. J’ai connu Pierre à Paris.
I met Pierre in Paris
The multiplicity of construals does not motivate referring tothe double object structure as an ‘inalienable possessionstructure’ any more than as a ‘goal structure’, etc.

However, just as we will misleadingly refer to the relation betweenthe BP DP and the POSS DP in Structures I–III as ‘inalienablepossession’ (IA), we will, also misleadingly, refer tostructures with disjoint DPs which permit this construal as ‘Inalienablepossession structures’ (IA-structures) in quotes, to designatethe single one of their possible construals which interests us. When discussing theories which do posit special IA structures, wewill use the term without quotes.

subsection.heading: 1.2 Constraints on IA in English
subsection.p: Structures I and II do not allow the IA construal in English:

(11)
Structure I
a. *John raised the hand. (cf. (7a))
b. *John gave the hand to Mary. (cf. (7b))

(12)
Structure II
a. *I took him the hand. (cf. (8a))
b. *I took the hand to/for the girl. (cf. (8b))
Structure I becomes grammatical in English – and ambigousbetween the alienable and inalienable construals – if wereplace ‘the hand’ by ‘his hand’:

(11′)
a. John raised his hand.
b. John gave his hand to Mary.

As the only difference between (11) and (11′) is theform of the determiner, the contrast between them suggests thatthe grammatical status of the definite determiner is crucial forthe IA construal on disjoint DPs. The French definite determinerpermits a construal in (7) which its English counterpart excludesin (11).

Extrapolating from the contrast between French (7) and English(11) in Structure I, we may attribute the ungrammaticality of theEnglish counterpart of Structure II in (12) in part to the construalof the definite determiner. Only in part, however, for StructureII does not allow the IA construal in English even if we replace ‘thehand’ in (12) by ‘his/her hand’ in (12′):

(12′)
a. *I took him his hand.
b. *I took her hand to/for the girl.

The contrast between French (8) and English (12) seems to beattributable to a different syntactic distribution of theta-rolesin the double object structure. In the French structure, the DATDP may be construed as either GOAL or SOURCE, as in (10a, b) above. Under the IA construal, however, the DATIVE may be construed asthe POSS DP only if it is SOURCE rather than GOAL, as in (13a). If the DAT is GOAL, only the subject may be construed as POSS DP, as in (13b):

(13)
a. Ils lui ont pris/arraché la main.
they to-him took/pulled out the hand
b. Ils lui ont donné/tendu la main.
they to him gave/extended the hand
In the English double object stucture, for some reason, the indirectobject is always Goal, never Source:

(14)
a. J’ai donné/prêté/venduun livre à Jean.
‘I gave/lent/sold a book to John.’
‘I gave/lent/sold John a book.’
b. J’ai pris/volé/arraché un livre à Jean.
*‘I took/stole/snatched a book to John.’
*‘I took/stole/snatched John a book.’

Other French structures which allow the IA construal may be assimilatedeither to Structure I, with subject as POSS DP, or to StructureII, with DAT POSS DP. They all exclude the IA construal in English:

(15)
a. Jean a les yeux bleus. (I)
b. *‘John has the blue eyes.’ 1

(16)
a. Marie est entrée, la tête haute. (I)
b. *‘Mary entered, the head held high.’

(17)
a. Jean a fait un geste de la main. (I)
b. *‘John made a gesture with the hand’.

(18)
a. Je lui ai mis de l’eau sur la tête. (II)
b. *‘I put (to) him water on the head.’
Like genitive DPs or double object sentences, these structuresallow the IA construal by accident, not by design: none of themis devoted exclusively to IA:

(19)
John a un livre.
‘John has a book.’

(20)
Marie est entrée, furieuse.
‘Marie entered, furious.’

(21)
Jean a fait un succès de son affaire.
‘John made a success of his business.’

(22)
Je lui ai mis de l’eau sur ses chassures.
*‘I put to him water on his shoes.’

subsection.heading: 1.3 Questions to answer
subsection.p: The IA construal raises the same syntactic questions as any otherconstrual involving disjoint nominals, such as anaphora, predication, or quantification:

li.p: What are the structural constraints on the IA construal?

How is the IA construal associated with the structures whichallow it? In particular, how can the POSS DP be construed simultaneouslyas a syntactic and semantic argument of V and as a semantic argumentof N?

What determines the difference between languages with respectto the IA construal? Can one predict which natural languages arelike French, and allow IA in Structures I–III, and whichare like English, allowing it only in Structure III? In terms ofacquisition, what information does a child need in order to concludethat her/his grammar contains sentences like (7) and (8)?

subsection.p: We will review the major literature in the generative frameworkwhich attempts to answer these questions. We will first examinesyntax-oriented theories. While these theories more or less adequatelyexpress the syntactic constraints on the IA construal, they turnout to be inadequate with respect to apparent semantic constraints. We then review theories of IA which integrate an explicit semanticfilter in their syntactic analyses. We will comment both on theempirical adequacy of these theories and on their status with respectto the principle of economy of the grammar.
The IA construal is subject to syntactic constraints:

row.entry: (Marie, en admirant Jean) *Les yeux bleus sont charmants.
‘(Marie, admiring Jean) The blue eyes are charming.’

Locality. The POSS DP must bein the same minimal sentential domain as the BP DP. (In (24) below, indices indicate an IA relation between Poss and BP DPs. In (25), indices indicate both the IA relation within the embedded sentenceand control of the subject of the embedded infinitival by an argumentof the matrix sentence.)
Jeanj seems [tj to her/himi totake the handi
Jeanj seems to him/heri [tj totake the handi)
‘Jean seems to him/her to take the hand.’
Jeanj a persuadé Mariei de [PROi leverla maini].
‘Jean persuaded Mary to raise her hand.’
*Jeanj a persuadé Mariei de [PROi leverla mainj].
‘Jean persuaded Marie to raise his hand.’
Asymmetric c-command. The Possessormust c-command the body part nominal or its trace:
L’ennemi luii a arraché la maini.
the enemy to-him pulled out the hand
La maini luii a été arrachéeti par l’ennemi.
the hand to him was pulled out by the enemy
*Le frère de Jeani a levé lamaini.
the brother of John raised the hand
the blue eyes are to Mary/Mary's
These same properties characterizethe independently established relation of anaphoric binding.

subsection.p:
(i)
Obligatory antecedent:
(30) a. John hates himself.
b. *I hate himself.

(ii)
Locality:
(31) a. John persuaded Maryi [PROi towash herself]
b. *Johnj persuaded Maryi [PROi towash himselfj]

(iii)
C-command:
(32) a. John perjured himself.
b. *John's mother perjured himself.

On the basis of the identity of the structural constraints onanaphora and on the IA construal of disjoint nominals, Guéron(1985) reduces the latter to a case of the former. The IAconstrual corresponds to one form of anaphoric binding, that ofobligatory control. In sentences like (5) or (6), the determinerof the BP DP is construed as PRO, a pronominal anaphor controlledby a c-commanding argument of the immediately dominating sententialdomain.
The (a) and (b) sentences of (33) and (34) are thus parallel:

(33)
a. Jeani veut [PROi venir]
b. Jeani lève [LAi main]

(34)
a. Je luii dis de [PROi venir]
b. Je luii prends [LAi main]

And just as PRO may have a generic or arbitrary (ARB) construalin the absence of a controller, a PRO determiner may have a genericor ARB interpretation under the same circumstances (cf. Authier 1990; Authier andReed 1992):

(35)
a. [PRO vivre] seul est désagréable.
‘[PRO to live alone] is disagreable.’
b. Il est important [PRO de savoir ce que l’onveut].
‘It is important [PRO to know what onewants].’

(36)
a. Avec ces gants, [les doigts] ne gèlentjamais.
‘With these gloves, the fingers never freeze.’
b. Un peu de natation muscle souvent [le dos].
‘A little swimming often develops the back muscles.’

Guéron accounts for the difference between French andEnglish with respect to Structures I and II on a morphological basis. The French determiner le, la, or les, markedfor number and gender, is homophonous with third person pronominalclitics marked for number, gender and person. Anaphoric bindingmay be assimilated to agreement in that it relates the theta-featuresof disjoint constituents. Guéron formulates the hypothesisthat only a determiner marked with theta-features may be identifiedin syntax as an anaphoric pronominal bound by an antecedent, derivingthe IA construal.

Her hypothesis makes the strong and testable prediction thatthe IA construal exists in Structures I and II only in languagesin which the definite determiner has variable theta-features whichidentify it as a pronominal, and that it is lacking in languagesin which the definite determiner is invariable. IA is thus predictedto exist in Romance, where the definite determiner is morphologicallyidentical to a pronominal, as well as in languages like Russian, which has both null pronouns with abstract phi-features and nulldeterminers. But it is predicted not to exist in languages likeEnglish, Arabic, or Hebrew, in which the definite determiner isinvariable.

Support for the hypothesis that the grammaticality of the IAconstrual in I and II depends on the existence of phi-features inthe determiner of the BP DP comes from English itself. Whereas IAis excluded in English when the BP DP has a definite determiner, it is possible with an indefinite determiner:

(37)
a. John wouldn't lift a finger to help.
b. Can you give me a hand?
c. Raise one hand for ‘aye’, two hands for ‘nay’.

(38)
a. We held hands/linked arms/rubbed noses.
b. She entered the room, arms akimbo.

Unlike the definite determiner the, the indefinite determinerhas a feature for number in English: ‘a’ is singularand zero is plural. Its number F suffices to identify the indefinitedeterminer as a pronominal subject to the binding relation whichunderlies the IA construal in I and II.
Syntactic and morphological constraints on the IA construal donot suffice to identify the set of grammatical ‘IA structures’, however. Lexical choice plays a crucial role.
Although Guéron identifies the IA construal with anaphoricbinding, many verbs which allow reflexive anaphora reject IA inStructure I:

(39)
Jean se lève.
Jean self raises

(40)
Jean lève la main.
Jean raises the hand

(41)
Jean se lave/se gratte/se chatouille.
Jean self washes/scratches/tickles

(42)
*Jean lave/gratte/chatouille la main.
Jean washes/scratches/tickles the hand

To account for these constraints on choice of verb, Guéron (1983, 1985) proposes thatunder the IA construal, in addition to their anaphoric relation, the POSS DP and the BP DP constitute two links of a LEXICAL CHAIN. The notion of lexical chain is weaker than that which characterizesa chain formed by A or A′ movement. Whereas the latterimply referential identity of antecedent and trace, a lexical chainrequires only non-distinctness of the referents of its links. Underthe IA construal, the BP being included in the body, the antecedentDP and bound DP have overlapping reference. They may thus constitutetwo links of a lexical chain. The assumption that two links of achain obey the same constraints as anaphora accounts for the localityrestriction on the IA construal. Independent constraints on chainsautomatically exclude certain IA structures which anaphora alonecould not filter out.

Every chain is asociated with a single theta-role. It followsthat IA is ungrammatical whenever the body part DP and the possessorDP are assigned two different theta-roles by the verb. The chainhypothesis thus accounts for the ungrammaticality of sentences like(42b) above (‘Jean lave la main’) in which thePOSS DP is AGENT while the BP DP is THEME.

A subset of such sentences is acceptable, however. This subsethas been described in semantic terms by Hatcher(1944) and Kayne (1975): the subsetof sentences of type I which are acceptable under the IA construaldenote a natural physical gesture.

Guéron proposes that in the acceptable structures, verband direct object are reanalyzed in syntax as a single verb. Underreanalysis the case and theta-features of the DO are absorbed bythe verb. At the level of construal, the subject binds the determinerof the body part N but, its theta-role having been absorbed at anearlier stage, the direct object is not associated with a theta-role, and the IA construal does not violate the theta condition on chains.
Reanalysis of verb and DO occurs in the grammar independentlyof IA. ‘Light verbs’ reanalyze with their objectto create an idiomatic complex verb:

(43)
a. John took his time/a shower/ten/a leak.
b. John had a fit/a ball/a hard time.
c. Mary made an error/an omission/her way through the crowd.

(44)
a. Jean a pris la fuite/une douche/son pied.
John took flight/a shower/his foot, i.e. had fun
b. Jean a fait une scène/une erreur/l’idiot.
John made a scene/an error/the idiot = played thefool

Reanalysis between verb and object deriving an idiomatic meaningmay also occur in reflexive structures. While the reflexive construalof V + DO is more or less transparent in (45), it is lessso in (46b), as Kayne has pointed out (class lectures in the seventies):

(45)
a. John washed himself.
b. John hates himself.

(46)
a. John threw Bill out the window (with his bare hands)
b. John threw himself out the window (*with his bare hands)

Reanalyzed V + direct object characteristically hasa special meaning. ‘Natural gesture’ is the special meaningwhich corresponds to syntactic reanalysis of an action verb + adirect object denoting a body part.
Structure II (8), in which the indirect object rather than thesubject is the POSS DP, accepts a greater variety of lexical choicesthan Structure I:

(47)
a. *Jean lave/gratte/chatouille la main. (= (42))
Jean washes/scratches/tickles the hand
b. Je lui lave/gratte/chatouille la main.

Guéron proposed the notion of lexical chain in orderto exclude non-reanalyzed cases of Structure I. The proposal thattheta-roles do not form a unified class makes it possible to usethe same notion to account for the greater lexical span of StructureII. Guéron distinguishes PRIMARY theta-roles, assignedlexically by the verb, from SECONDARY theta-roles, which are notlexically assigned. Only PRIMARY theta-roles count for the theta-rolecondition on lexical chains as stated in (48):
(48) A lexical chain is associated with a single primarytheta-role.
AGENT, PATIENT, THEME are primary theta-roles selected by V. The sentences of (47a) above are excluded by (48) because two primarytheta-roles are associated with a single lexical chain.

The sentences of Structure III (example (9)) III all containa dative DP construed as a BENEFACTIVE (BEN) argument. The BEN theta-roleis not selected by the verb: it is acceptable in any structure containinga direct object (DO) and a verb which denotes an action (cf. Leclère (1978) for a detailed account).

The transitive verb of (49a) and the unaccusative verb of (49b) license a BENEFACTIVE argument because they select a direct objectand denote an action. But unergative (50), which lacks a DO, excludes theBENEFACTIVE dative, as does any structure like (51) in which VPdenotes a state rather than an action:

(49)
a. Jean lui a cassé sa poupée (à lapetite fille).
Jean to-her broke her doll (to the little girl)
b. Il lui est arrivé quelque chose.
it to-him happened something = something happenedto him

(50)
*Je lui cours.
I run on him

(51)
*Je lui aime sa bicyclette.
I like her bicycle to her

A DAT DP may be construed as inalienable possessor of a definitedirect object denoting a body part in the very same syntactic environmentsin which it is construed as a BENEFACTIVE when the DO does not denotea BP or has a genitive determiner. Transitive (52a) and unaccusative(52b) are acceptable but unergative (53) and stative (54) are not:

(52)
a. Je lui ai pris la main.
I to-him took the hand
b. Les bras m’en tombent t.
the arms to-me fall over that

(53)
*La tête lui bouge.
the head to-him moves

(54)
*Je lui aime les mains.
I to-her like the hands

Guéron identifies the POSS DP with the BENEFACTIVE DP. Only the lexical content of the direct object distinguishes thetwo construals. Being non-selected, the benefactive has only a secondarytheta-role. A lexical chain containing dative BEN plus nom. or acc. THEME is therefore compatible with the chain criterion (48).

An argument in favor of the hypothesis that the POSS DAT is asubcase of BEN DAT in French is the fact that any difference ofacceptability between full NP and clitic dative under the BEN construalof the dative also pertains under the possessor construal. In French, the BEN and the POSS DP preferably or obligatorily take the formof a clitic (cf. Dorel 1980; Nicol1997).

(55)
a. Je lui ai pris la main.
b. ?? J’ai pris la main à Pierre.

(56)
a. Le bandeau lui enveloppe la tête.
b. *Le bandeau enveloppe la tête à ce garçon.

(57)
a. Je lui ai mis de l’eau sur la tête.
b. *J’ai mis de l’eau sur la tête à Jean.
In languages such as Hebrew, in which either the full dativeDP or the clitic is an acceptable BENEFACTIVE, the same is trueof the DAT POSS DP under the IA construal (Landau1999).

Any analysis of IA must account not only for the contrast betweenFrench and English in Structures I and II, but also for the lackof contrast between them with respect to Structure III. Guéron(1985) proposes that III illustrates not A- but A′-binding. In (58) below, the BP DP contains an empty category (ec) argumentof the relational head N. The e.c. is construed as a variable A′-boundby the possessor DP outside the nominal domain:

(58)
I hit Johni [PP on [DP the headei]]
J’ai frappé Jeani [PPsur [DP la tete ei]]

As suggested above, A-binding may be reduced to feature-agreement. In particular, it depends on the existence of phi-features in thebound nominal. A′-binding links not phi-features but ratheroperator Fs such as +wh, NEG, or Focus. It thereforedoes not manifest phi-feature dependencies.

A-binding, a form of phi-feature agreement, occurs, like otherforms of agreement, within a single argument domain. A′-binding, on the contrary, links an argument within an argument domain toan operator on the periphery of this domain. There is thus a complementarydistribution between the IA construal in I and II, in which bothDPs are in a single argument domain, and that in III, in which thebody part DP is within an adjunct to the VP or sentence which containsthe POSS DP.

IA is thus predicted to occur freely in Structure III in alllanguages which manifest A′-binding, including those inwhich, as in English or Hebrew, an invariable determiner blocksthe A-binding IA construal in I and II.
Guéron's hypothesis simplifies the grammarby reducing the unknown, the principles governing the IA construal, to the known, the grammatical principles governing A- and A′-binding.
The analysis has a number of problems, however:

(i) Guéron claims that the relation betweenthe disjoint DPs in I and II is anaphoric binding, like reflexivizationor control. Yet in sentences like (59), the number and gender Fsof the BP DP do not match those of the POSS DP. This situation createsungrammaticality in reflexive or control structures, as shown in (60). So it is not clear what motivates the proposed binding relationbetween the subject and the direct object in (59):

(59)
Le jeune hommei a levé les mainsi.
sg. m. pl. fem.
‘The young man raisedhis hands.’

(60)
a. *Le garçoni si’est levé elles-memesi.
m. sg. pl. fem.
the boy self raised themselves
b. *Jeani veut [PROi partirseulesi]
John wants PRO to leave alone
m. sg. m. sg. f. pl.

(ii) Guéron's analysis has recourseto ad hoc auxiliary hypotheses. As Koenig (1999) points out, Guéron pays for the simplicity of reducingIA to anaphora in I and II with a new and otherwise unnecessarytype of chain, which does not imply identity but only non-distinctnessof its links.

(iii) The distinction between PRIMARY and SECONDARYtheta-roles, which Guéron uses to exclude most cases oflexical chain in Structure I, while including a larger number ofcases in Structure II, is another unwelcome innovation. Furthermore, it wrongly predicts that structures like (61), which contain twopredicates each of which presumably assigns a Primary theta-roleto its subject, are ungrammatical.

(61)
a. Ellei est entrée [la têtei haute].
b. Mariei a [les cheveuxi blonds].

(iii) The hypothesis that Verb and DO are reanalyzedas a single verb in Structure I is plausible, but no explanationis given for the semantic constraint on the output. Why is reanalysislimited to VPs which denote gestures, rather than, say, thoughts, feelings or intentions? Reanalysis of verb and object in idioms oftendenotes, on the contrary, feelings:

(62)
a. Mon coeur n’a fait qu’un bond.
‘My heart made but one leap = I reactedstrongly.’
b. J’ai les boules.
‘I have the balls = I'm nervous.’
c. Ce spectacle m’a arraché des larmes.
‘This show ripped out tears from me.’

(63)
a. She wears her heart on her sleeve.
‘She reveals all her feelings.’
b. My heart fell t.
Subsequent syntax-based analyses of IA assimilate the IA construalto other independently established syntax-sensitive construals suchas binding or predication.
Tellier proposed that IA structures, like Topicalization, RelativeClause or Tough-movement, reduce to A′-binding plus Predication:

(64)
a. Johni [OPi I like ti].
b. Maryi is tough [Opi PRO totalk to ti].
c. The man [Whomi you met ti].

Tellier proposes that DP, like CP, is an argument domain. Anec argument of the head N may be construed as a variable bound byan operator at the periphery of the domain. The operator is identifiedby a referential DP outside the domain, deriving a predication construal.
Whereas virtually all verbs take arguments, only some Ns do. Tellier distinguishes (non-deverbalized) Ns which take arguments, such as body-part or kinship terms, from Ns such as dog, which do not.

In (65), the ec complement of the relational N main isconstrued as a variable A′-bound by an operator in SpecDP. This operator is identified by the closest DP, lui, construedas subject of the predication:
(65) Je luii prends [Opi lamain ei].
Tellier cites the occurrence of parasitic gaps in IA to supportthe A′-binding hypothesis not only for Structure III, asGuéron did, but also for Structures I and II:
(66) This is a book that I read t before buying e.

(67)
a. Jeani a mis [la main ti] sur [latête ti].
John has put the hand t on the head t
b. Les cheveuxi lui descendent ti de [latête t] aux [pieds t].
the hair to-her descends from the head e to the feet t
Tellier was one of the first linguists to argue for the hypothesisthat non-deverbalized Ns may have an argument structure and thatDP functions, like CP, as a domain for A′-binding and predication.

The A′-binding hypothesis overgenerates with respectto IA, however. While all relational Ns can project argument ecssubject to A′-binding, not all of these admit the IA construal. Kinship terms, for example, which are intrinsically relational andallow A′-binding and parasitic gaps, cannot replace a BPDP in an ‘IA structure’:

(68)
a. un garçon dont je connais le père.
a boy of-whom I know the father
un garçon [CP donti [IPje connais [DP Opi le père ti]]]
b. un garçon dont le père se dispute avecla mère.
a boy of whom the father quarrels with the mother
un garçon [CP donti [Opi lepère ti] se dispute avec [Opi lamère ei]].

(69)
a. *Je lui ai frappé [le père t].
I to-him hit the father
b. *Je lui ai poussé [la mère t] contre [lepère e].
I to-him pushed the mother against the father
Nor does wh-type A′-binding into a DP obey thesame lexical constraints as the IA construal:

(70)
a. une fille dont Jean admire [le corps t] plusque [l’âme e].
a girl of whom Jean admires the body more than the soul
b. *Jean lui admire le corps/l’ame.
Jean to-her admires the body/soul
Moreover, Nouns which do allow an ‘extended IA’ construal, such as items of clothing and objects held in the hand, typicallylack lexical arguments:

(71)
a. Jean a tombé la veste.
‘Jean dropped the jacket.’
b. Ho perduto l’ombrello. (Italian)
‘I have lost the umbrella.’

Finally, the A′-binding + Predication hypothesisdoes not account for the contrast between English and French in ‘IAstructures’. English has the same relational Ns and sententialA′-binding and Predication structures as French. Thereforethe theory incorrectly predicts that it will have the IA construalin Structures I and II, just as it has it in Structure III.

Vergnaud and Zubizarreta (V&Z) also assimilate IA topredication but without an A′-binding component. For V&Z, the body-part N functions as a predicate which contains an implicitempty category construed as a variable. This variable can be boundby a determiner functioning as an operator or else by a DP externalto the predicate domain, construed as subject of a predication. In (72), the predicate variable in N is bound by the dative DP:

(72)
a. Je lui prends la main.
je luii prends [DP la [NP main]]
vbli
According to V&Z, Predication is subject to the structuralconstraint of M-Command (Williams 1980): thesubject DP and the predicate NP must mutually c-command each other.

It appears at first glance that M-command does not hold in (72), where dative lui c-commands the predicate NP main butDP, a maximal projection, blocks c-command of lui by main. V&Z propose, however, that D projects a maximal projectionDP only if it has a construal. If the determiner is identified asan expletive, a dummy element, then it does not project a DP, andthe nominal is analyzed as NP. The assumption that la in(72) is an expletive allows M-command between lui and theN main, deriving the predicational IA construal.
M-command also seems to be lacking in (73), where la main ccommands Marie but the latter is embedded in a maximal projection, PP, which blocks c-command of the BP NP by the POSS DP:

(73)
J’ai pris la main à Marie.
J’ai pris la main [PP à Marie]
V&Z propose that à not being a lexicalP but merely a case assigner, it does not project a PP capable of blockingc-command of the BP NP by the Poss DP; once again predication obtains.

For V&Z, as for Guéron, the construal of thedeterminer of the BP DP underlies the difference between Frenchand English in Structures I and II. For them, the crucial factoris not the morphology of the determiner but its semantic construal. The contrast in (74) shows that, in French, the definite determinercan function as an expletive element, while in English it cannot:

(74)
a. Jean admire la beauté, la charité et labonté.
b. *‘John admires the beauty, the charity and the kindness.’

V&Z further argue that the syntactic distinction betweenNP with expletive determiner and DP with meaningful determiner hassemantic consequences. NPs denote types while DPs denote tokens. Under the IA construal, the BP NP denotes a type. This is why itdoes not allow non-restrictive adjectives, which only modify tokens:

(75)
a. Je lui ai pris la main.
I to-her took the hand
b. *Je lui ai pris la belle main.
I to-her took the beautiful hand

According to V&Z, the claim that the BP NP has a typereference under the IA construal is supported by the fact that itis subject to backward pronominalization. Backward pronominalizationis a property of coreference, not of anaphora or binding:

(76)
Parce qu’elle est fragile, le médecin leura couvert la tête d’une cagoule.
because it is fragile, the doctor to-them covered the headwith a hood
V&Z identify an NP with a type construal as a targetof distributivity. They further seem to identify distributivitywith inalienable possession.
In (77), the plural subject triggers a distributive construalof the type BP NP. Although the N estomac is singular, itis construed as having plural reference:

(77)
a. Le médecin a examiné l’estomacaux enfants.
b. Le médecin leur a examiné l’estomac.
In English, where D functions as an operator, not as an expletive, and the body-part Noun is construed as a token, not a type, thedistributive interpretation would not be available:

(78)
a. The doctor examined the children's stomachs.
b. *The doctor examined the children's stomach.
V&Z suggest that NPs which denote types and are subjectto a distributive construal, as in (79), define a class of ‘extendedIA structures’:

(79)
On a donné le même ordinateur, à Marie, Jeanne, et Suzanne.
‘We gave the same computer to Mary, Jean, and Sue.’
For Structure I, V&Z adopt the reanalysis proposal of Guéron (1983, 1985).

For Structure III, acceptable in both French and English, V&Zpropose that the BP DP and the POSS DP form a ‘metonymicbinding chain’. In (80) below, the plural direct objectbinds the determiner of the BP NP containing the semantic variable. This binding relation is licensed by semantic metonymy:

(80)
I kissed the children on the cheek.
J’ai embrassé les enfants sur la joue.
This hypothesis, like all the others reviewed here, has empiricaland theoretical problems.

(i) The M-command requirement on predication incorrectlyrules out structures in which the BP NP is embedded in a PP witha lexical P head. In (81), the dative DP c-commands the BP NP butthe PP projection of the lexical P sur blocks c-command ofthe dative by the BP DP:
(81) Je luii ai mis de l’eau [PPsur [NP la têtei]].
In (82), a small clause (sc) projection prevents M-command:

(82)
Il a [sc la main heureuse]/[lesepaules larges]/[la taille fine].
he has [the hand happy] [the shoulderslarge] [the waist thin]
In (83), the sc containing the BP NP is adjoined to VP. But c-commandbetween an argument of a sentence and an element in an adjunct isnever symmetrical, as (84) shows:

(83)
Elle est entrée, [sc la tête haute]/[lescheveux en desordre].
she is entered [the head high] [thehair disheveled]

(84)
a. Maryi entered the room [PP without PROi smiling].
b. *[[PROi to enter the room [PPwithout Maryi smiling]] is unusual.

(ii) V&Z propose that Predication depends onthe structural relation of M-command. However, as Koenig(1999) points out, they subject M-command to an interpretiveconstraint: the BP NP c-commands the POSS DP only if its determineris construed as an expletive. To define a semantic condition ona syntactic relation is to abandon the autonomy of syntax hypothesisand thus to weaken the grammar.

(iii) Koenig (1999) also pointsout an empirical problem with the analysis: distributivity is notin fact excluded from nominals with genitive DP in English. He cites(85a, b), which for me are slightly marginal. However I find (86a, b) perfect:

(85)
a. ?The doctor examined the children's stomach.
b. ?The children all raised their hand.

(86)
a. Children, before speaking in class, you must raise your hand.
b. The guests are having trouble finding their place at thedinner table.
Distibutivity into a possessive DP with prenominal genitive isperfect in French:

(87)
a. Le médecin a examiné leur estomac.
‘The doctor examined their stomach.’
b. Les messieurs ont enlevé leur chapeau.
‘The gentlemen took off their hat.’
c. Les invités cherchent leur place à table.
‘The guests are looking for their place at the table.’
As a DP with a genitive determiner denotes a token, not a type, distributivity cannot in general require a type interpretation ofthe target nominal.
V&Z are no doubt correct to identify distributivityas a property of predication, but apparently wrong to identify distributivitywith the IA construal.

Distributivity may target a VP whose direct object, if present, need not refer at all, not even to a type. Distributivity is a propertyof all sentences with idiomatic VPs, in which the direct objecthas no reference (it does not lend itself to leftward pronominalization), neither token nor type:

(89)
a. The children threw a fit/*?fits.
‘The children had a tantrum.’
b. The explorers gave up the ghost/*ghosts.
‘The explorers died.’
c. We’ll hit the road/*roads now.
‘We’ll leave now.’
d. OK you guys, take a powder/*powders.
‘Ok you guys, leave!’

When not lexically triggered by an operator such as each, distributivity is semantically triggered whenever a plural DP issubject of a predicate which can only apply to one individual ata time. The predicate may or may not contain an object:

(90)
a. John, Sam, and Bill died/were born in 1940/got married lastyear.
b. My children love me.
c. Three dogs bit Bill.

Finally, the distributive interpretation of a DP does not implythat it is subject to the IA construal. Structure (91), in which lemême ordinateur is construed distributively is notan ‘IA structure’ at all. Under the IA construalof a double object structure, the dative DP must be SOURCE not GOAL(cf. (13) above). (91) and (92) show that a non-BP DP object hasa distributive reading only if the IO is GOAL not SOURCE. The conditionsunderlying the distributive reading of a non BP-DP are thus distinctfrom those underlying the same reading of a BP DP:

(91)
a. On a donné le même ordinateur à Marie, Jeanne, et Suzanne.
b. *On a donné la main à Marie, Jeanne, etSuzanne.

(92)
a. On leur a ecrasé la main (à Marie, Jeanneet Suzanne).
b. *On leur a acheté le même ordinateur (à Marie, Jeanne, et Suzanne).

Neither Guéron nor V&Z accounts for the factthat the IA construal is not always excluded in English when theBP DP has a definite determiner. In English, IA is excluded in StructureI if the BP N has no modifier, as in (92), but is acceptable, asin French, if N has a restrictive modifier, as in (93) and (94):

(92)
a. Jean lève la main.
b. *John raises the hand.

(93)
a. Jean a levé la main droite (pas la main gauche).
b. Jean a levé la main qui etait blessée.

(94)
a. I asked John to raise the right hand (not the left one).
b. John raised the hand which was wounded.
If the definite determiner functions as an operator in (92), as both theories claim, it must not so function in (93) and (94).

The lack of contrast between English and French in (93) and (94) recalls structure III, which has the same status. Can the two groupsof examples have something in common which has so far been overlooked?

subsection.heading: 2.4 The Possessor-Raising hypothesis (Szabolsci 1983; Landau1999)
subsection.p: If IA is the name of a construal associated with a variety ofstructures, there is nothing to say about the derivation of ‘IAstructures’: there is no such grammatical object.

There is a respectable literature devoted to an alternative theory, however. Under the Possessor-Raising hypothesis, a POSS DP is generatedwithin a DP denoting a possessed item, and raises out of its hostto a position in VP in syntax. This hypothesis has been advancedfor possessive structures in general in both relational grammarand in generative grammar.
Szabolsci (1983) claims that in Hungarian a dative POSS DP generatedwithin the DP denoting a possessed object can and sometimes mustmove out of its host.

Hungarian has two possessive structures. In both of them, thepossessed object agrees in phi-features with the possessor. Thestructures differ in that the lexical POSS DP is marked NOM in onecase (95) and DAT in the other (96). The possessed DP may denotea BP or any other nominal such as ‘a guest’, ‘ahat’, etc.:

(95)
a. az en-0 kar-ja -i - m
the I-NOM arm-poss-pl-1sg.
‘my arms’
b. az en-0 vendeg-e-m
the I-NOM guest-poss-1sg.
‘my guest’

(96)
a. en -nek- e - m a kar-ja -i - m
I-dat-poss-1sg. the arm-poss-pl-1sg.
to me DAT the arms
‘my arms’
b. en -nek-em a vendeg- e- m
I dat -1sg. the guest-poss-3sg.
to me DAT the guest
‘my guest’

A NOM POSS DP is located to the right of the definite determiner az whilea DAT possessor is to its left. Szabolsci proposes that the NOMDP is in Spec Infl within DP while the DAT DP is in a type of Spec COMPposition, Spec Komp. Thus DP and CP have analogous structures, withboth subject and peripheral Spec positions.

Support for this hypothesis comes from wh-movement, whereComp functions as an escape hatch for movement in both the nominaland the sentential domain. A DAT DP located in Komp may raise outof its nominal host to a higher position in the sentence, whilea NOM DP in Spec IP may not.

In Hungarian, all FOCUS elements, including wh-elements, obligatorily move to a Comp-like Focus position in the sentence. So whenever the possessor is a wh-word it must be markeddative, as in (97), and raise to the Focus position. The wh-markedDP may raise as a whole (98), or else the Dative POSS DP in KOMPmay raise independently (99):

(97)
ki-nek a kar-ja-0
who-dat the arm-poss-3sg.

(98)
[FOCP kinek a karja]i hosszuti
to-who the arm (is) long?

(99)
[FOCP kinek]i hosszu [DPti a karja]
to-who (is) long the arm?
Landau (1999) makes a similar claim forstructures containing a POSS DATIVE in both Hebrew and French.

Landau proposes that in both languages, the POSS DP is generatedin the Spec position of the DP which denotes the possessed object. In Modern Hebrew, Dative case cannot be checked in this position, so the DAT Poss DP obligatorily raises to Spec VP, the only positionin which DAT case can be checked:

(100)
a. Gil sataf le-Rina et ha-panim.
Gil washed to-Rina ACC the face
Gil sataf [VP le-Rinai [DP ti etha panim]]
b. Gilles lui a lavé la figure.
Gilles luii a lavé [DP ti lafigure]
As in Hungarian, the possessed object may denote not only a bodypart but any concrete object:

(101)
a. ha-yalda kilkela le-Dan et ha-radio.
the girl spoiled to Dan acc. the radio
b. Gil savar le-Rina et ha-miskafayim.
Gil broke to Rina acc. the glasses
Again as in Hungarian, topicalization and wh-movementshow that the POSS DP and the BP DP can be disjoint, as expecteduner the Possessor-Raising hypothesis (cf. Borerand Grodzinsky 1986):

(102)
[li] hem kilkelu [et ha-radio], ve-[laxem] hem kilkelu [et ha-televizia].
to me they spoiled acc. the radio and-to-you they spoiledacc. the-tv

(103)
[le-mi] ha-yalda kilkela [et ha-radio]?
to who the girl spoiled acc. the radio
‘Whose radio did the girl spoil?’
The Possessor-Raising hypothesis neatly accounts for locality, obligatory antecedent, and C-command constraints on IA as propertiesof movement.
Furthermore, the Possessor-Raising hypothesis accounts for localityconstraints on IA better than Guéron's controlhypothesis. Control occurs not only into an argument but also intoan adjunct:

(104)
a. Jean a voulu [PRO danser].
b. Jean est venu [pour PRO danser].
c. Jean a dansé [sans PRO tomber].

In Hebrew, however, although the POSS DP can bind a trace withineither a direct object DP or one embedded in a locative, directionalor instrument PP, it cannot bind into a purpose or privative adjunct:

(105)
a. Gil yasav le-Rina ba-mitbax. LOC PP
Gil sat to Rina in the kitchen
b. Gil ganav le-Rikna me-ha-tik. DIR PP (SOURCE)
Gil stole to Rina from the bag
c. Gil hitkaleax le-Rina im ha-sabon. INSTR PP
Gil bathed to Rina with the soap

(106)
a. *Gil pitpet le-Rikna lem’an ha-hofa’a. PURPOSE
Gil chatted to Rina for the performance
‘Gil chatted for the benefit of Rina'sperformance.’
b. *Gil hitaleax le-Rikna bli ha-sabon. PRIVATIVE
Gil bathed to Rina without the soap
‘Gil bathed without Rina's soap.’

As A-movement is blocked from an adjunct, the Possessor-Raisinghypothesis automatically accounts for the ungrammaticality of thesentences of (106), while the control hypothesis incorrectly predictstheir well-formedness.

Construal is also simpler under a movement hypothesis than underthe binding hypothesis. Under the movement hypothesis, the POSSDP is construed in the position of its trace, movement having beentriggered for formal reasons alone. The semantic relation of possessionis explained by whatever accounts for the same relation within aDP: Landau proposes that the POSS DP receives a possessor theta-rolefrom the D head. The possessor construal need not be derived frombinding or from the notion of ‘lexical chain’.

Landau makes an interesting attempt to account for lexical constraintson IA in purely structural terms. Recent theories propose the existenceof both a VP and a vP node in the sentence (cf. Chomsky2000). While the VP node is always projected, vP, situateddirectly above VP, is projected only if the verb selects an Agentargument.

Landau assumes that dative case can only be checked in Spec VP, and that Hebrew lacks VP shells (cf. Larson 1988b). So Possessor Raising must fail if Spec VP is already occupied byan argument in d-structure. Agentive transitive verbs like wash or spoil acceptPossessor Raising because they select an Agent argument merged inSpec vP. Spec VP is free to lodge the raised dative possessor:

(107)
Gil sataf le-Rina et ha-punim.
Gil washed to Rina the face
[IP Gilj sataf [vP tj [VPle-Rinai tv [DP ti et ha panim]]]]
Spec VP can also host a POSS DAT when V is unaccusative:

(108)
ha-kelev ne’elam le-Rina.
the dog disappeared to Rina
[DP ti he-kelev]j ne’elamle-Rinai [tj]

But a transitive verb such as like or see, with two internalarguments, THEME and EXPERIENCER or PERCEIVER, excludes possessorraising. In (109), for example, the second internal argument occupies SpecVP, and there is no position in which dative case can be checked. In terms of the Minimalist framework of Chomsky(1995c), (109) crashes because it contains an unchecked uninterpretablecase feature:

(109)
*Gil ra’a le-Rina etha-punim.
Gil saw to Rina the face
[IP Gilj [VP tj ra’a [DP le-Rina et ha panim]]]
NOM *DAT ACC

If Landau's analysis of the POSS DAT in Hebrew extends, as he claims, to IA structures in French, then Guéron'sanalysis of IA as anaphoric binding must be incorrect. Under heranalysis, the acceptability of IA in French II, which is parallelto POSS DAT structures in Hebrew, requires a determiner with phi-features. Languages like Hebrew or Arabic, with invariable definite determiner, should not have the ‘IA Structures’ I and II, but, like English, only Structure III.
The Possessor-Raising analysis encounters both theoretical andempirical problems, however.

Chomsky (2000) tightens the grammarby eliminating case checking as a motivation for movement. If oneadopts this approach, then POSS DP raising is not forced by casechecking, and there must be another F which triggers it, at leastwhen the moved element is not wh-marked. But it is not clearwhat this F could be, since the DP is construed in its originalposition.

In Hungarian and Russian, as well as, apparently, in earlierHebrew, a POSS DP with oblique case generated within DP can stayin situ rather than raise to VP or CP. The fact that a (non-wh-) possessor DP can remain in the position in which it is generatedand construed sheds doubt on the Possessor-Raising hypothesis altogether. If a POSS DP can check its FFs in the Spec DP which includes it, then it must do so, for reasons of economy, by the Principle ofLast Resort (Chomsky 1995c).

Possessor Raising violates a well-established constraint on extraction: extraction from a DP with a definite determiner is grammatical onlyif DP is construed as non-specific (cf. Enç 1991). This construal usually requires that the main verb have existentialforce, thus, that it does not presuppose the referentiality of itsdirect argument. Verbs which imply physical change of the denotatumof the direct object exclude extraction to the degree that theypresuppose the existence of the physically affected object:

(110)
a. Who did you meet/see/recognize/look for [the brotherof t]?
b. *Who did you wash/beat/kill/spit at [the brotherof t]?

Yet the same type of sentence which excludes wh-extractionbecause the object is bodily affected by the action of the verb, is the only type which allows the IA construal. Verbs with an existentialconstrual, which do not affect the object and therefore allow wh-extraction, reject the IA construal.

(111)
a. Je lui ai lavé/pincé/écrasé lebras.
b. *Je lui ai cherché/vu/reconnu le bras.
The fact that Possessor Raising violates the well-establishedspecificity constraint on extraction from DP sheds further doubton its existence.

Nor is there any necessity for a DAT DP to raise to Spec VP inHebrew in order to check its case there. A DAT DP is already mergedin Spec VP under its other, non-possessive, construals. Borer and Grodzinsky (1986) distinguish threeconstruals of the dative in Hebrew: reflexive, benefactive, andpossessive. Each construal is subject to syntactic and thematicconstraints. Only the possessive DAT functions as an argument undergoingmovement. The possessive and the benefactive may take either fullor clitic form but the reflexive only has clitic form. Under thepossessive construal, the dative is obligatorily associated withan object in VP; under the reflexive construal, it is obligatorilyassociated with the external argument; while under the benefactiveconstrual it takes scope over the VP as a whole. These propertiessuffice to distinguish three construals of the same syntactic object. As none of them can be shown to depend on movement, the simplesttheory generates the DAT DP in VP as a single syntactic constituentsubject, in Hebrew as in French, to a variety of construals at thesyntax–semantics interface.
The hypothesis that perception verbs block raising of the POSSDAT DP on the basis of their theta-grid leads Landau to excludegrammatical (112) from the data to be explained by his theory:

(112)
Gil ra’a le-Rina et ha-pupik.
Gil saw to-Rina acc. the belly-button

Landau notes that sentences like (112) are acceptable under apossessive construal only if the acc. DP denotes a body part oran item of clothing. He considers such structures ‘quasi-idiomatic’: they are acceptable only if they involve embarrassment to the possessorof the body part. The more intimate the body part, the easier itis to have Possessor-Raising with a perception verb.
Instead of eliminating such structures from consideration, onemay, on the contrary, consider them as crucial evidence that theIA construal is not determined by the theta-grid of the verb.

Cheng and Ritter (1987), among others, proposed, on the basis of contrasts like that between between (109) and (112), that the acceptability of IA structures depends on thesemantic notion of affectedness: the referent of the BP DP mustbe affected by the action the verb denotes. Landau challenges thisclaim with a list of examples in which the possessed object is clearlynot affected. A ring which one seeks is not affected by the action; it may not even exist. A kitchen is not affected by people laughingin it:

(113)
a. Gil xipes/maca le-rina et ha-taba’at.
Gil sought/found to Rina acc. the ring
b. Gil madad/cilem le-Rina et ha gina.
Gil measured/photographed to Rina acc. the garden

(114)
a. Gil caxak le-Rina ba-mitbax.
Gil laughed to-Rina in the kitchen
‘Gil laughed in Rina's kitchen.’
b. Gil histakel le-Rina al ha-kova.
Gil looked-at to Rina on the hat
‘Gil looked at Rina's hat.’

The evidence provided in (113) and (114) to show that the POSSDAT structure in Hebrew lacks an affectedness constraint suggeststhat the analysis of this structure cannot be extended to the French ‘IA structure’ II, which is subject to such a constraint.

The data suggest that the Hebrew structure is not in fact an ‘IAstructure’ at all, but, rather, a ‘possessive structure’, which, like all possessive structures, can denote IA if it happensto contain both a [+human] DP and a BPnominal. The examples of (113) and (114), which show the absenceof affectedness, crucially do not contain body-part DPs. The discussionof (112) shows that affectedness does apply whenever the DP happensto be a body part (or an article of clothing). Only those Hebrewstructures which contain body-part objects are comparable to StructureII in French. Hebrew possessive structures with non-body-part DPsdon't even exist in French with a possessive rather thana benefactive reading:

(115)
a. Je lui ai cherché/trouvé la bague.
I to her looked for/found the ring
b. Je lui ai photographié la cuisine.
I to-her photographed the kitchen
c. *Je lui ai ri dans la cuisine.
I to-her laughed in the kitchen

In French, the IA construal of Structure II is a subcase of thebenefactive construal of the same sentence. In Hebrew, the IA construalof Structure II is a subcase of the possessive construal of thesame structure, just as for French son bras/son livre orEnglish his arm/his book, except that the POSS DP and theBP nominal are disjoint in Hebrew.
That the IA construal is not a subset of BEN construals in Hebrewis shown by the ordering of constituents. In French both BEN andPOSS DP may follow the possessed object DP:

(116)
a. J’ai cassé sa poupée à Marie. BEN
I broke her doll to Marie
b. J’ai pris la main à Marie. POSS
I took the hand to Marie

In Hebrew, however, the DAT DP precedes the possessed objectunder the possessive construal but follows it under the BEN construal. Thus the possessor interpretation is obligatory only in (117a). In (117b), le-Rina has a Benefactive interpretation, andthe face can be either Rina's or Gil's, accordingto Landau:

(117)
a. Gil sataf le-Rina et ha-punim. (= (107))
Gil washed to-Rina the face
b. Gil sataf et ha-panim le-Rina.
Gil washed the face to-Rina
Similarly, when a non-body part, the dative DP is construed asbenefactive in (118a), where it follows the object, and possessiveonly where it precedes the object, as in (118b):

(118)
a. Gil lakax et ha-tik le-Rina.
Gil took acc. the bag for Rina
b. Gil lakax le-Rina et ha-tik.
Gil took Rina's bag

Whether the IA construal is a subset of the set of BEN construals, as in French, or of the set of possessive construals, as in Hebrew, the data show that affectedness is pertinent for the IA subset whetheror not it is a property of the non-IA superset.

subsection.heading: 3 Semantic or conceptual based theories of IA
subsection.p: The structure-based theories of IA presented above do not filterout all the ungrammatical IA construals. Affectedness is one typeof semantic constraint on some cases of IA. Other, apparently lexical, constraints also turn out to involve a semantic calculation.

(i) Constraints on verbs In structure I, it is not somuch the choice of verb which is restricted as the interpretationof the structure. As mentioned above, Hatcher(1944) and Kayne (1975) note thatthe VP must describe a simple physical gesture. (119a) contrastsin grammaticality with (119b) because ‘lever la main’ denotesa physical gesture while ‘laver la main’ doesnot.

(119)
a. Je leve la main.
I raise the hand
b. *Je lave la main.
I wash the hand
In most cases of IA, the VP must denote an action, not a state.

(120)
a. Je leve la main.
I raise the hand
b. *Je regarde la main.
I look-at the hand

(121)
a. Je lui prends/gratte/chatouille la main.
I to-her take/scratch/tickle the hand
b. *Je lui aime/admire/adore la main.
I to-her like/admire/adore the hand

(122)
a. I hit Bill on the hand.
b. *I admired Bill on the hand.
The contrasts between (109) and (112) in Hebrew and between (123a) and (123b) in French show that the notion of action goes beyondlexical definition:

(123)
a. *Je lui vois la figure/la tête/le nez.
I see to-him/her the facé/the head/the nose
b. ?Je lui vois les jambes/le ventre/le cul!
I see to-him/her the legs/the stomach/the ass

Under the IA construal, the action of the verb must affect thebody part DP. (123b) is better than (123a) because in traditionalsociety, a look at a person's private body parts is experiencedas a quasi-physical attack. (123) should be less acceptable in anudist colony, or when discovering a body buried under an avalanche, where there is presumably no embarrassment and no ‘affect’.

(ii) Constraints on adjectival modifiers Under the IAconstrual, the BP DP may not contain a non-restrictive adjective, which does not restrict the set of objects which N denotes, as in(127) below, but represents, rather, the point of view of the speaker, as in (124b):

(124)
a. Jean a levé la main.
b. *Jean a levé la belle main.
This constraint is a general property of DPs containing a boundvariable:

(125)
a. un homme dont j’ai rencontré [labelle-fille t]
a man I met [the daughter-in-law of t]
b. *un homme dont j’ai rencontré [labelle fille t].
*a man I met [the beautiful daughter of t].

(126)
a. Everyone loves his son.
b. *Everyone loves his intelligent son. (OK if restrictive)

The reference of a DP with a semantic free variable, whetherit is syntactically PRO, a wh-item, or a covert predicatevariable, depends on the successful construal of a binding relationat the syntax–semantic interface. The insertion of an evaluativeadjective like ‘belle’ in (125) or ‘intelligent’ in(126) presupposes the referentiality of the evaluated object independentof the truth value of the sentence. This creates a semantic contradiction.

The insertion of a restrictive modifier, on the other hand, asin (127), does not create a presupposition of referentiality butmerely adds a restriction to the definition of the set of objectsN denotes:

(127)
a. Jean a levé la main gauche.
b. Jean a levé la main qui a été blessée.
That it is its (non-) restrictive construal, not the adjectiveitself, which is crucial for IA is shown in (128) below, from Nicol (1997):

(128)
a. Je lui ai lavé la main sale.
b. *Je lui ai lavé le nez sale.

(iii) Only body part DPs participate in IA Thisconstraint on the IA construal is largely correct. Although it ispossible to extend the IA construal to a limited class of objectsin contact with the body, such as clothing or objects held in thehand, in no case may a physically separate object such as a member ofthe family participate in a structure construed as IA rather thanBenefactive:

(129)
a. Jean tombe la veste.
b. Ho perduto l’ombrello.
c. *Elle lui lave le fils.
d. *Elle soulève le cousin.
Italian, unlike French, appears to allow kinship terms underthe IA construal:

(131)
a. Gianni e Maria non hanno aiutato neppure la (propria) figlia.
b. *Jean et Marie n’ont meme pas aidé la (propre) fille.
However, as Delfitto and D’hulst (1995) point out, Italian, unlike French, allows a genitive pronoun betweenthe det and the head N:

(132)
a. la sua figlia
b. *la sa/sienne fille
Moreover Italian, unlike French, has null pronominals. (132) is not an ‘IA construction’ at all, but a standardpossessive structure, equivalent to sa (propre) fille inFrench.
In order to account for these apparent semantic factors, somelinguists have incorporated explicit semantic conditions into theiranalyses of IA. These analyses happen to target mainly structureII.

subsection.heading: 3.1 Cheng and Ritter (1987)
subsection.p: Cheng and Ritter posit the same IA structure for Mandarin Chineseand for French. The structure contains P and V heads which assignan ‘affected theme’ theta-role. This theta-rolefunctions indirectly as a lexical-semantic filter on the construal.
(133a) and (b) in Mandarin correspond to (134a) and (b) in French.

(133)
a. Ta ba Lisi da-shang-le shou.
he BA Lisi hit-wounded-ASP hand
‘He (prt) wounded Lisi's hand.’
b. Ta ba juzsi bo-le pi.
he BA orange peel-ASP skin.
‘He (prt) peeled the skin from the orange.’

(134)
a. Il a lui blessé la main (à Marie).
b. *Il lui a epluché la peau (à l’orange).

Although French admits only body part DPs under the IA construalwhereas Chinese allows part–whole relations in general, the relevant structure is subject to the same constraints in bothlanguages. Locality must be respected. The DP cannot contain a non-restrictiveadjective. The relation excludes kinship terms and alienable possession: son maynot replace the BP NP hand in (133a) nor may a pronoun replace orange in(133b). The DP must be affected by the verb.
(133c) shows the structure of (133b) in Mandarin:

In (133c), both the particle ba and V peel assignthe theta-role “affected theme” (af.th). The complement ofthe verb is a small clause (NP1) whose subject (NP2) is an ec boundby the preverbal NP and whose predicate (NP3) denotes the possessednominal. Lack of non-restrictive adjectival modification in IA automaticallyfollows from the predicative status of NP3.

In Logical Form, NP3 raises onto the verb, forming a complexpredicate. In (133), the verb peel and the sc predicate skin jointlyassign the theta-role of ‘affected theme’ to thepreverbal NP orange which binds the small clause subject.

This syntactic analysis of Structure II does not extend to other ‘IAstructures’, however. In (135a), two Ns would raise toV, one of which is embedded in a PP, which is a barrier to syntacticraising in French. In (135b) the two raised Ns are predicates ofdifferent NPs; but no verbal predicate, not even a complex one, can have two subjects:

(135)
a. Je luii ai mis la maini sur la têtei.
b. Je luii ai mis la mainj sur la têtei.

Unlike French II, the Mandarin structure is not limited to bodyparts but includes part–whole relations, while eschewingkinship terms. Interestingly, Structure III in English and Frenchhas the same property:

(136)
a. I took the baby by the arm.
b. I took the pot/the knife by the handle.
c. We sang the song from the beginning (to the end).
d. We climbed the mountain to the top.

(137)
a. *I wounded him on/through/via the son.
b. *I dragged him with the daughter.

(138)
a. J’ai pris le bébé par le bras.
b. Je lui ai lu l’histoire du début à lafin.
c. J’ai pris le couteau par le manche.

(139)
a. *Je l’ai blessé par le fils.
b. *Je l’ai pris avec la fille.

Instead of taking IA as the construal of disjoint DPs sharedby Structure III in English and French and Structure II in Mandarin, we may instead take the less lexically restricted part–wholeconstrual of the disjoint DPs as basic. Then, just as IA is a subconstrualof possession in genitive DPs in general and in structures withdisjoint DPs in Hebrew, and a subconstrual of BEN structures inFrench II, it is a subconstrual of the part–whole interpretationof disjoint DPs in Mandarin II and in English and French III. Nostructure is limited to the IA construal.

subsection.heading: 3.2 Koenig (1999)
subsection.p: Koenig adopts anaphoric control as the syntactic theory of IA, and adds to it a semantic constraint based on a kind of affectedness.

An IA structure would be one which contains a body-part NP witha lexically inserted covert reflexive possessor subject. The covertsubject is construed as PRO and is subject to anaphoric binding, as in Guéron (1983, 1985). Allstructures containing the configuration (140), in which a DP withanaphoric possessor is bound by an antecedent, are subject to asemantic constraint involving the denotatum of NP1 and that of NP2with respect to the situation the sentence describes:
(140) NP1i . . . NP2Possi

(141) Semantic Constraint on the Antecedent of a BodyPart NP in the Inalienable Possession Construction: An NP1 can onlybe the antecedent of the (unexpressed) possessive anaphor of a BPNP2 if the BP is the active zone of the referent of NP1 (Koenig 1999: 238).

Let x and y be two entities filling the argumentpostions O1 and O2 in the same sentence. x is the active zoneof y iff the semantic role entailments which characterizeO2 are true of x (Koenig 1999: 239)
(141) accounts for the grammaticality of (142–144) below:

(142)
Jean a poussé la balle de la main.
Jean pushed the ball with the hand

(143)
a. Marie lui a lavé les pieds.
Mary to-him washed the feet
b. Marie a lavé les pieds au saint homme.
Mary washed the feet to the holy man

(144)
Les pieds nous demangent.
the feet us itch

In (142), the NP Jean (= y in (141)) hasthe theta-role of ACTOR. The theta-role entailment of an ACTOR isthat it causally initiates the action in which it participates. The active zone of Jean is that part of his body which bears that same entailment. Since Jean may not initiate the actionof pushing the ball without the hand also causally initiating theaction, the actor entailment holds of both the hand (= x in (141)) and Jean. So (142) passes the semantic filter (140).

In (143) lui/le saint homme has the BENEFICIARY/MALEFICIARYtheta-role whose theta-role entailment is that the bearer profit/sufferfrom the occurrence of the event. In (143) both lui/lesaint homme and les pieds profit from the event.
In (144), both nous and les pieds have the theta-roleentailment of the PATIENT of the action (les pieds havingan additional role of cause).

In ungrammatical (145), however, Marie is ACTOR but lespieds does not share its theta-role entailment: les pieds donot causally initiate the action. (145) is ungrammatical becauseit violates the Semantic Constraint (140).

(145)
*Marie a lavé les pieds.
Mary washed the feet

Koenig concludes that the necessity for Constraint (140) to filterIA structures which binding theory alone accepts shows that thegrammar can impose non-configurational semantic conditions on syntactic processes. In particular, model-theoretic notions such as theta-role entailmentsmust be available to grammatical description.

The semantic filter proposed by Koenig has the advantage of recognizing, and attempting to make explicit in terms of the notion ‘activezone’ the fact that affectedness involves not only theverb and the BP DP in a sentence but also the relation between thePOSS DP and the BP DP with respect to the situation they participatein.

The empirical coverage of the analysis is insufficient, however. It predicts that (140) should function in the same way for all IAstructures since all of them contain the configuration (139). Itthus cannot account for the contrasts in (146) and (147). Although lenez or la main is the active zone of the antecedent DPin both sentences, only one of the sentences is grammatical:

(146)
a. Je l’ai frappé sur le nez.
b. *Je lui ai frappé le nez.

(147)
a. Le lutteur a écrasé la main à sonadversaire.
b. *Le lutteur a écrasé son adversaire à lamain.

Moreover, the notion active zone suggests that IA sentences invariablydenote actions. But IA can be construed on a stative sentence also. It is hard to interpret ‘les yeux’ or ‘lesepaules’ as having any active zone relation to Jean in(148):
(148) Jean a les yeux bleus, les epaules larges, etc.

The crucial claim that the antecedent DP and the BP DP must sharethe same theta-role entailments in an IA-structure cannot be tested, for no independent criterion of a theta-role entailment is given. One way to test theta-role entailments is by syntactic distribution: two NPs must have the same theta-role entailment if they appearin the same syntactic environments. But BP DPs, which are [−animate], do not appear in the same syntactic environments as AGENTS and BENEFACTIVESwhich are typically [+animate]:

(149)
a. Jean a battu Pierre avec ses mains nues. AGENT
‘Jean beat Pierre with his bare hands.’
b. *Les mains de Jean ont battu Pierre.
‘The hands of Jean beat Pierre.’

(150)
a. J’ai cassé le pied à Jean. BEN
‘I broke the foot to Jean.’
b. *J’ai cassé le pied à la table.
‘I broke the foot to the table.’

(151)
a. Beulah, peel me a grape. BEN
b. *Beulah, peel the fruit salad a grape.

Similarly, the subject in (152a, b) is a BEN or PATIENT, whichbears the brunt of the state which the verb denotes. But as lespieds cannot replace il in (152c), what motivates theclaim that the two DPs have the same theta-role entailment?

(152)
a. Il souffre des pieds.
‘He is suffering in the feet.’
b. Il souffre.
‘He is suffering.’
c. *Ses pieds souffrent.
‘His feet are suffering.’

Finally, the analysis makes no attempt to situate IA within thetheory of grammar. Each language would have its own list of IA constructions. If so, one should expect each language to have its own list of control, anaphora, wh-, focus, passive-middle constructions, etc. While this is true, descriptively, to some extent, much progress has been made towards deriving individualconstructions from a general theory of principles and parameters. The assumption that each language has a list of specific syntacticstructures is a step backwards.

subsection.heading: 3.3 Jackendoff (1996), Nicol(1997)
subsection.p: For Cheng and Ritter (1987), affectednessis a lexical-semantic Feature of the THEME theta-role assigned bythe particle ba in Mandarin and by certain verbs in Mandarinand French. For Koenig (1999), affectednessis a semantic constraint on IA, which somehow intervenes in thesyntactic derivation, although it is not clear where and how.

Jackendoff (1996) is more explicit onthis last point. He proposes a grammar with parallel structuresin which phonological, syntactic and conceptual rules all feed aderivation. Semantic or phonological principles can block or favora syntactic structure at any point in the derivation via correspondencerules which link the separate components:
(153) PHONOLOGY xharr Corr. rules xharr SYNTAX xharr Corr. rules xharr CONCEPTUAL STRUCTURE

Nicol (1997) applies Jackendoff'smodel to the grammar of IA. Nicol addresses the question why theIA Structure II is more productive in French with a clitic thanwith a full dative POSS DP. He proposes that the answer to thisquestion lies in the correspondence rules linking Syntax to ConceptualStructure.

Although V&Z treat the full and clitic dative formsas equivalent, Dorel (1980) had alreadyshown that while both forms are acceptable under the GOAL construalof the DAT DP, this is not always the case under the BENEFACTIVEor IA construals:

(154)
a. Marie a donné un cadeau à son pere. GOAL
Marie gave a present to her father
b. Elle lui a donné un cadeau.

(155)
a. Marie a cassé son jouet à Pierrot. BEN
Marie broke his toy to Pierrot
b. Marie lui a cassé son jouet.

(156)
a. Jean a caressé la joue à Marie IA
Jean carressed the cheek to Marie
b. Jean lui ai caressé la joue.

(157)
a. Marie va lui casser la vaisselle. BEN
b. *Marie va casser la vaisselle à sa mere.
Marie will break the dishes to her mother

(158)
a. Jean lui a donné un coup dans les dents. IA
b. *Jean a donné un coup dans les dents à Max.
Jean gave a blow in the teeth to Max
Nicol notes that all speakers accept both the clitic and thefull form with dynamic verbs, in particular under an idiomatic construal:

(159)
a. Paul tirait les cheveux à sa petite soeur.
Paul was pulling the hair to his little sister
b. Paul lui tirait les cheveux.

(160)
a. Le fisc casse les pieds aux contribuables.
the taxman breaks the feet of (harrasses) the taxpayers
b. Le fisc leur casse les pieds.

(161)
a. Cet incident a ouvert les yeux à Marie-Jeanne.
this incident opened the eyes to Marie-Jeanne
b. Cet incident lui a ouvert les yeux.
In the standard dialect of French, however, sentences like (162a), cited by V&Z as grammatical (cf. (77a) above), are acceptableonly with a clitic, not with a full DP:

(162)
a. *Le docteur a examiné la gorge à la petitefille.
the doctor examined the throat to the little girl
b. Le docteur lui a examiné la gorge.

Nicol reviews in detail the distribution of clitic and full DATIVEDPs in Structure II in terms of the lexical-semantic type of theverb, the target of its action, and the affect of the action onthe BP DP and/or the Poss DP. He distinguishes three classes ofverbs: type A accepts only the clitic, type B accepts neither cliticnor full DP, and type C accepts both clitic and full DP.
Type A: verbs of static contact, lacking ‘affect’: coller, toucher, envelopper, effleurer, etc.:

(163)
a. *Les bandelettes enveloppaient la tête à lamomie.
the bands envelopped the head to the mummy
b. Les bandelettes lui enveloppaient la tête.

(164)
a. *La robe colle à la peau à Christine.
the dress sticks to the skin to Christine
b. La robe lui colle à la peau.
Type B: verbs of inchoative contact and of impact: atteindre. attraper, blesser, frapper, poignarder, taper, etc.:

(165)
a. *Le jeune homme a attrapé/blessé le visage à son agresseur.
b. ?? Le jeune homme lui a attrapé/blessé levisage.
Type C: verbs which imply dynamic contact or change of statewith affect: serrer, enlacer, briser, casser, éclaircir, nettoyer, amputer, inciser, lever, pousser, traîner, etc.:

(166)
a. Il a serré la main à son pire ennemi.
he shook the hand to his worst enemy
b. Il lui a serré la main.

(167)
a. Il a cassé le bras à son adversaire.
he broke the arm to his opponent
b. Il lui a cassé le bras.

(168)
a. La charbon noircissait le visage aux mineurs de fond.
the coal blackened the visage to the miners
b. La charbon leur noircissait le visage.

(169)
a. Le chirurgien a amputé le bras au soldat.
the surgeon amputated the arm to the soldier
b. Le chirurgien lui a amputé le bras.

Nicol proposes that every IA structure is linked by a correspondencerule to a lexical conceptual structure (LCS). The same verb mayappear in several structures, linked to as many LCS. The sentencesof (170) correspond to two LCS, which both include the dynamic LCprimitive GO:

(170)
a. Le blesséi a levé la jambej.
the wounded man raised the leg
b. L’infirmieri leva la jambej aublessék.
the nurse raised the leg to the wounded man
LCS (172) corresponds to structure (170b). It differs from (171) in that it contains a causative notation in the first line and includestwo affected participants instead of one in the third line:

Nicol proposes that an IA structure with full lexical Dativeis acceptable only if (i) the LCS contains the conceptual primitiveGO, (ii) the direct object is TARGET of the action, and (iii) thedative DP is AFFECTED.
The ill-formedness of stative (173) is due to the absence ofthe GO primitive in its LCS. And that of (174a), which contrastswith (174b), is due to the absence of AFFECT in its LCS:
(173) *Je lui ai admiré les jambes.

(174)
a. *La belle prit la main au Prince. (Type B)
b. Le judoka prit le bras à son adversaire. (Type C)
Structure III is related by a correspondence rule to an LCS inwhich there is an AFFECT primitive, but no TARGET. In such cases, the Affect is global.

Nicol also locates the difference between English and Frenchwith respect to Structure II in the determiner of the BP DP, notin its morphology, like Guéron, nor in its construal, likeV&Z, but via a language-specific correspondence rule ofEnglish which targets the determiner.

Structures I and II are associated with an LCS in which the BPDP corresponds to a TARGET of AFFECT, while Structure III is associatedwith an LCS with global affect: not only the BP but the POSS DPis affected by the action of the verb. English has a special correspondencerule, (171), which requires Global rather than local AFFECT whenever the determines a DP denoting a possessed item:
(175) [DO the N] = Possessor = [+Affected: [−Target]]

Nicol concludes from his detailed study of the distribution ofthe DAT DP in Structure II that syntactic analysis alone cannotdistinguish grammatical from ungrammatical IA structures. Each structuremust be linked to an LCS which functions as a semantic filter onits construal.

Nicol's analysis shows that the semantics of the IAconstrual is more complex than was previously supposed. AFFECT isnot a defining property of all IA structures: there is no affectin class A of Structure II (cf. (59–60)). When affect isa property of IA, it may be targeted, as in French I and II, orglobal, as in Structure III.
The analysis has weak spots, however. One concerns the justificationfor parallel grammatical components, the other the notion of affect.

In Jackendoff's LCS component, a vocabulary of primitiveconceptal notions combine to form LCS formulas which correspondencerules link to syntatic structures. Any theory of grammar which relatessyntax and meaning must, like Jackendoff's, assume theexistence of a limited repertory of semantic primitives, and mustfurthermore relate each syntactic structure to a meaning. It isnot evident, however, that LCS formulas and correspondence rulesare necessary to accomplish these tasks. It must be shown that agrammar with less machinery, which maps primitive conceptual notionsdirectly onto the morphemes of a syntactic output, and interpretsthese as a function of the compositional interpretation of the syntacticstructure, cannot give the same results as one which appeals inaddition to LCS and correspondence rules.

Under Nicol's account of IA, the correspondence ruleswhich link syntactic structures to LCS are subject to language-particularconstraints, such as that which stipulates that all IA structuresin English must have global affect. Such an account is descriptiveat best, rather than explanatory.

The non-equivalence of the theta-role entailments of POSS andBP DPs raises the question of the pertinence of the notion ‘affect’. This notion is never defined, for good reason: it changes from structureto structure. In structures with BEN dative, affectedness refersto the psychological consequence of a situation on an individual. In ‘IA structures’, affectedness, when pertinent, involves physical contact. Psychological affect may be construedas a quasi-physical attack, as shown by Hebrew (112) and French(123), and by the idioms based on IA in (176):

(176)
a. (i) Il a perdu la tête. (Structure I)
(ii) He lost his head.
b. (i) Tu me casses les pieds. (Structure II)
(you to me break the feet = you bore me)
(ii) I gave him a piece of my mind.
c. (i) Je l’ai regardé droit dans les yeux. (StructureIII)
(ii) I looked him straight in the eye.

Inanimate objects are not subject to psychological affect, so handles cannotreplace legs in structure II. Yet handles can easilyreplace legs in Structure III. Affect must therefore referto something different in III than in II:

(177)
Je lui ai vu les jambes (à Marie).
I to-her saw the legs (to Marie)

(178)
*Je lui ai vu la poignée, à la casserole.
I to-it saw the handle, to the pot

(179)
a. John pulled her by the arm.
b. I picked the pot up by the handle.
Finally, not all ‘IA structures’ involve affect(cf. (180)). Whatever it is, affect is not a general property ofthe IA construal:

(180)
a. Les bandelettes lui couvrent le front.
the bands to her cover the forehead
b. Les cheveux lui descendent de la tête aux pieds.
the hair to her descends from the head to the feet

subsection.heading: 4.1 IA as anaphora
subsection.p: ‘Alienable’ as well as ‘inalienablepossession’ often involves phi-feature agreement betweenthe possessor DP and the possessed NP. In Romance possessives, thehead agrees in number and gender with a pronominal genitive. Inthe English genitive, either the prenominal POSS DP is a pronoun(‘my book’) or D bears an ‘s morpheme(‘John's book’) which functions as anAGR head (cf. Zribi-Hertz 1998). In Hungarian, the N which denotes a possessed item agrees in number and genderwith the possessor.

Other possessive structures do not manifest phi-feature agreementbetween the POSS DP and the possessed N. Such is the case in Frenchwhen the POSS DP is post-nominal (‘les livres de ma cousine’ – ‘the books(m. pl) of my cousin (f.sg.)’), or when the DAT possessorand the possessed object are disjoint, as in Hungarian, Hebrew, or English III.

This last point may be incorrect, however. Perhaps Guéron (1983, 1985) was too hastyin concluding that the definite determiner does not function asa pronominal in English. The theory of the IA construal would beunified in an elegant manner if the definite determiner could beconstrued not only as an operator or an expletive, but also as apronominal.
In English, the definite determiner has pronominal properties. The TH morpheme of the corresponds to a deictic F in thedemonstrative paradigm THIS, THAT, THOSE.
Like pronouns and unlike anaphors, demonstratives, with or withouta head N, trigger coreference over a sentence boundary:

(181)
a. The apples look good.
b. They are good.
c. Allow me to offer you this one.
d. This is the best one.
Like pronominals and unlike anaphors, the demonstrative can haveostensive reference.

(182)
a. Thank God he left (said of an obstreporous guest).
b. This is beautiful.
Like pronominals, demonstratives denote only objects when theyvary in phi-features but they denote predicates and propositionswhen they are invariable:

(183)
a. Mary est belle.
f. f.
b. Je le/*la sais.

(184)
a. John is sick, and he won'tcome to the party.
b. (i) I know it/*them.
b. (ii) I know that/*those.

(185)
a. Mary is both beautiful and smart.
b. That/*those she is.

Let us add the to the paradigm of demonstrative pronominalsbearing a deictic F. We may now characterize the IA construal asanaphora in the widest sense, including both anaphoric and pronominalbinding.
