Unlike pronouns or deictic this/that, the definitedeterminer may not appear without an accompanying N in English orFrench:

(186)
a. It is too big.
b. This is too big.
c. *The is too big.
d. The box is too big.
However, in other languages, such as Spanish, an isolated determinermay be construed as a head modified by a clause:

(187)
El bañarse immediatamente despues de comer es peligroso.
(The to-swim right after to-eat is dangerous)

The contrast between the and the box in (18c, d) recalls a similar contrast between bare wh-words like French que orPortuguese que, and full wh-DPs such as quel livre or quelivro. The bare forms have a more restricted distribution thanthe full forms (cf. Ambar 1987, for a fulldiscussion):

(188)
a. Je sais quand/où/à qui tu as parlé.
b. *Je sais que tu a dit.

(189)
a. Que livro a Joana comprou?
(What book Joana bought?)
b. *Que a Joana comprou?
(What Joana bought?)
Like the bare WH morpheme, the bare TH morpheme needs a lexicalitem to determine its range, in place of its missing phi Fs.
The hypothesis that the may be construed as a pronominalmorpheme in the boy just as le may be construed asan anaphoric morpheme in le bras illuminates certain propertiesof IA.
Like a pronominal or a deictic element, ‘the N’ participatesin discourse anaphora. There need not even be an antecedent if theintended referent is unique in context:

(190)
a. A boy entered. He sat down.
b. A boy entered. The boy sat down.

(191)
a. Get him out of here.
b. The sun is shining.
c. John and Mary sold the car.
d. I forgot to turn off the gas.
‘The N’ can be related to a discourse antecedentby metonymy as well as by identity:

(192)
a. Le roi est mort. Les drapeaux sont en berne.
b. The king is dead. The flags are flying at half-mast.
This is harder for a pronoun, which normally has to match itsantecedent in phi-features, yet it can be forced:

(193)
a. I saw the Joneses last night.
b. *I like him.
c. I like HIM better than HER.
The pronominal determiner one is construed referentiallywhen it has a F for number, and generically when it does not:

(194)
a. These pears are for sale.
Give me the firmest ones.
b. One does what one can to survive.
*Ones do what ones can to survive.
The, having no phi-features, also allows generic reference:

(195)
a. Dr Jones has studied the kidney for years.
b. Mrs Smith often goes to the opera.

Most often, however, the is not generic, but functionsas a pronominal linked to a discourse topic. The N predicate ofthe DP is linked to the topic by a part–whole or metonymyrelation. The discourse topic may be created explicitly, like thebody or the Jones family in (196), or it may be derivedimplicitly from the lexical items in the sentence, like the implicit ‘thebody’ in (195a) or the information that John and Mary owna car in (198c):

(196)
a. The hand is an important part of the body.
b. When swimming, one should keep the hands close to the body.
c. In the Jones family, the father does all the housework.

(197)
a. These gloves keep the fingers warm as toast.
b. Swimming is good for the back.

(198)
a. Gianni e Maria hanno venduto la machina.
b. Jean et Marie ont vendu la voiture.
c. John and Mary sold the car.
V&Z argue for the hypothesis that the BP DP has a typedenotation by showing that backward pronominalization, which isa criterion for coreference rather than binding, applies to FrenchIA:

(199)
Parce qu’elle est sensible, le médecina décidé de leur protéger la têted’une cagoule.
(Because it is sensitive, the doctor decided to protect tothem the head with a hood)

Backward pronominalization also occurs in English, however, where, according to V&Z, nominals refer to tokens rather thantypes. The evidence of (200) suggests that backward coreferenceis not type reference associated with NP, but normal pronominalcoreference of two DPs. 2

(200)
a. Because they are so sensitive, the doctor said to keep theeyes out of the sun at all times.
b. Because it is still fragile, the doctor advised keeping thearm in a sling for two weeks more.
c. Because it is a gas-guzzler, John and Mary sold the car.
More precisely, it seems that in all cases of backward pronominalization, the sentence implies a discourse topic to which the pronoun andthe full DP refer independently.

Just as pronouns are in complementary distribution with anaphors, pronominal the hand is in complementary distribution withanaphoric la main. An anaphor is used when a bound pronominaland its antecedent are co-arguments of the same domain, while apronominal is used if they are in different argument domains. Thus, PP contains an anaphor when V and P define a single predicate, asin (201a), but a pronoun in (201b), where PP functions as an adjunct(i, ii) or as predicate of a small clause (iii, iv).

(201)
a. (i) She threw water on herself/*her.
(ii) Mary told stories about herself/*her.
(iii) Mary has a fixation on herself/*her.
b. (i) Come sit beside me/*myself.
(ii) Mary heard stories about her/?? herself.
(iii) She saw a serpent next to her/*herself.
(iv) She put the key behind her/*herself.
In the ‘IA Structure’ III, the definite determineris embedded in an adjunct, which excludes anaphors. The in(201c) replaces the pronoun in (202b) not the anaphor in (202a):

(202)
a. *I hit him on himself.
b. I hit him on his arm.
c. I hit him on the arm.

The construal of the French determiner le with respectto IA may target either its phi-features or its [+D] F. In the first case, le N is a bound anaphor in StructuresI and II. In the second case, le N is a bound pronominalin Structure III. In English, the IA construal is not possible instructures like I and II because its definite determiner lacks phi-features.

Because the domains of anaphoric and pronominal binding are complementary, we may conclude that whenever English has the same ‘IAstructure’ as French, the determiner is functioning asa pronoun in both languages. As noted above, the antecedent andbound DP are in different domains when the latter is in a PP adjunctin Structure III. They are also in different domains even in StructureI whenever the determiner of the BP DP defines an argument domaindistinct from that of its antecedent.
Consider the sentences in (203) and (204), which are grammaticalin both English and French:

(203)
a. Le médecin a demandé à Jean delever la main droite. 3
b. ? The doctor asked John to raise the right hand.

(204)
a. Le medecin a demandé à Jean de lever lamain qui lui faisait mal.
b. The doctor asked John to raise the hand which hurt him.
Following Kayne (1994), we propose thatthe addition of restrictive material in sentences like (204) allowsthe determiner to function as the head of a restrictive relativeclause internal to DP:
(205) [CP1 He raised [DP the [CP2handi [C′ whichi [IPti hurt]]]]]
Extending this analysis to (203), we may take le to functionin general as an anaphoric element within the syntactic domain ofits governor, but as a pronominal when it heads its own syntacticdomain.

subsection.heading: 4.2 [+D] asa phi-feature
subsection.p: Phi Fs may be either formal features (FF), destined to be erasedin syntax after checking, or referential features (RF), destinedto be construed at the interface. For example, number and personare formal features on predicates but referential features on arguments. Korean has a FF for ‘honorificity’ which is a morphologicallyvisible agreement F on V, but an intrinsic RF of certain lexicalitems such as ‘mother’ or ‘professor’ (cf. Kang 1999). Gender is a FF in French which appears on N, A, andparticipial heads, but a RF in English, where no lexical head ismarked for gender. The same morpheme may carry a FF in one contextand a RF in another. In English, s is a referential numberF on N (book vs. books) but a formal [nb. + pers.] Fon V (John runs) and a formal person F on D (John'sbook). In Hungarian number and person (but not gender) are formalFFs which appear on N or V under agreement with a DP in Spec Agr.

Formal Fs on a head are valued under agreement between the headand a DP in its Spec position. They are also valued on an N headunder local binding, as in reflexive sentences, which also fallsunder F-agreement. RFs appear on the DP which determines agreementin Spec, or binds an anaphor within an argument domain or a pronominalover domains.

In English, [+D] is a referential, pronominal F which is bound over argument domains, as in Structure IIIor in sentences like (203b) and (204b) above. But nothing preventsa language from treating [+D] as a FFunder local agreement.
The Construct State (CS) DP in Hebrew exhibits agreement in ‘definiteness’ betweenDP in Spec AGR and the N head which raises from AGR to D:

(206)

‘Definiteness’ would correspond to the construalof [+D] as a formal O-F defining an agreementrelation between the DP in Spec AGR and the N head. When N raisesto D, the locus of reference in DP, the formal +D F ofN is construed as a referential F, establishing the referentialityof the DP as a whole. Raising from N to D has the function of changingthe construal of +D from FF in AGR to RF in D.

When the Possessor and the possessed object are distinct DPsin Hebrew, [+D] is a referential F. Thisis shown by the fact that the POSS DP may be related to the possessedobject over a PP boundary, as in (207). This boundary blocks anaphoricrelations such as agreement, binding or A-movement:

(207)
Gil niskav le-Rina al ha-mita.
Gil lay to-Rina on the bed
‘Gil lay on Rina'sbed.’

Anaphora is local agreement involving FFs while pronominalizationis non-local agreement between referential Fs. [+D] functionsin Hebrew as a formal F below D and as a referential F in D. +Dis solely a referential F on D in English and French. If it werea FF, we might expect those languages to have CS. But neither Englishnor French have a referential DP without a pronominal specifieror a (in)definite determiner to carry the +D F. In French, in the absence of a +D phi-F, a Noun can obtain a +DRF under Spec-Head agreement on the CP level within DP, as illustratedin (208b), perhaps via transfer of the referential +D Fof the determiner to the formal +D F in the particle de inComp:

subsection.heading: 5 Semantic constraints on IA and the Minimalist Program
subsection.p: The minimalist framework of Chomsky (2000) integrates the hypothesis of Distributive Morphology (Halleand Marantz 1993) according to which syntactic nodes containonly the formal features necessary to trigger ‘merge’ and ‘move’. Words are inserted late, in the phonology. Construal at the interfacemust then be limited to the interpretation of referential Fs andthe syntactic configurations in which they appear.

Certain primitives of Jackendoff's theory could functionat the syntax–semantics interface as the conceptual counterpartsof referential Fs. The syntactic articulation of these RFs wouldbe determined compositionally on autonomously derived syntacticstructures.

Notions such as GO or IDENTITY plausibly correspond to FFs ofverbal heads construed as RFs and concepts at the interface. Suchnotions are easy to grasp and necessary throughout the grammar. GO distinguishes states from events. This distinction is crucialfor filtering verbal forms like the progressive, and for matchingtime adverbials with VPs. IDENTITY translates a F on the copulawhich distinguishes predicative from identificational sentences(‘John is my best friend’ vs. ‘My bestfriend is John’) and is necessary to derive cleft and pseudo-cleftconstruals.

Other notions which are essential for construal correspond toentire sub-structures, not to syntactic heads. ‘Part of’ in(172) and (173) above is a concept which is both easy to grasp andcrucial for the construal of partitive DPs and for filtering extractionfrom DP of French en or Italian ne, but it requiresdefining relations between nominals within a structure.

A conceptual primitive may be easily construable and independentlynecessary in the grammar yet not be crucial for the IA construal. GO, which is a plausible semantic primitive, is not pertinent forthe construal of the IA examples of (209):

(209)
a. Marie a les yeux bleux.
Marie has blue eyes.
b. Elle est entrée la tête haute.
She entered, head held high.
c. Les cheveux lui descendent de la tête aux pieds.
Her hair goes down from her head to her feet.

As for AFFECT, this notion, if it is one, cannot be defined ona head, as it must at the least relate a nominal to a situation. Nor is it easy to grasp, as its meaning changes with each structure, nor is it a necessary property of IA.

The fact that no syntax-based analysis of IA has yet been ableto account for the interpretive constraints which filter these structuresdoes not imply that such analyses cannot do so in principle andthat the syntactic component must incorporate semantic constraints. The theories we have sampled above, which propose semantic constraints, are unable to account for the full range of the data.

What needs to be discovered is a still unknown FF or Fs whosereferential counterparts interact at the syntax–semanticsinterface with other formal features and with the construals ofsyntactic configurations to derive the equivalent of affect whereit is needed, in dynamic IA sentences, for example, but not where itis unwanted, in stative sentences.

Some of the formal and lexical Fs which are crucially involvedin the semantic calculus of IA have already been discovered: Formalphi-Fs and the [+D] F, lexical Fs suchas [+animate] and the semantic ‘body-part’ Fwhich together changes a ‘possessive’ construalinto an ‘IA’ construal. Crucial syntactic constraintsinclude c-command, locality, and whatever defines an argument domain. The missing FF will interact at the interface with these other Fsand with the construal of the sentence as denoting an action ora state. As the list of FFs available to natural language is small, the missing feature or features should not be impossible to identify.
